marketNews.title: Compilation of Stock Buybacks by Emitters
marketNews.content: Several issuers have announced plans to buy back shares amid market volatility. This move is also supported by the relaxation from OJK, which allows issuers to conduct share buybacks without the need for General Meeting of Shareholders (RUPS) approval for six months starting from 19 March 2025. marketNews.title: Key Takeaway
marketNews.content: We assess the issuers' buybacks, as well as a number of buybacks from controlling shareholders and directors, as potentially fostering optimism among domestic market participants. However, for a more significant IHSG recovery, increased confidence from foreign investors is needed so that the foreign outflow trend can reverse. Since the beginning of 2025, the IHSG has recorded a net foreign outflow of IDR 49.5 trillion as of Thursday (17/4).

marketNews.title: Other Hot Items You Need to Know
marketNews.content:
1. Gold spot prices on the market touched an all-time high of USD 3,357 per troy ounce in intraday trading on Wednesday (16/4) before closing at USD 3,342 per troy ounce (+3.5%). Since the start of 2025, gold has risen about USD 700 per troy ounce (+27.6% YTD), supported by global uncertainty and a weakening US dollar due to trade war escalation. On Thursday (17/4) gold weakened 0.53% to USD 3,325 per troy ounce.
2. Newcastle coal futures for April 2025 fell 1.3% to USD 94.25 per ton on Wednesday (16/4), marking the lowest level since May 2021. Coal prices have declined in recent months as demand from China fell amid oversupply, while China's monthly coal production reached an all-time high in March 2025.
3. Chinese President Xi Jinping on Thursday (17/4) promoted the idea of an "Asian family" and called for regional unity to counter US pressure on countries to limit trade with China. The idea was presented during his visit to Cambodia, concluding his Southeast Asia tour after stops in Vietnam and Malaysia.
4. The US Census Bureau reported that US retail sales surged 1.4% month-on-month in March 2025 (vs. Feb 2025: +0.2% MoM), beating the consensus estimate of +1.3% MoM and marking the strongest growth since January 2023. The increase was driven by higher motor vehicle and parts sales (+5.3% MoM) as consumers accelerated purchases ahead of potential import tariffs. Excluding automotive, core retail sales grew 0.5% MoM in March 2025. Core retail sales, which move similarly to the consumer component of US GDP, grew 0.4% MoM (vs. Feb 2025: +1% MoM), below the consensus of +0.6% MoM.
5. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said on Wednesday (16/4) that the Fed will wait for more data on the economic direction before changing interest rates. Powell warned that US President Donald Trump's tariff policy could push inflation and unemployment further from the Fed's targets. He also noted that US economic growth appears to be slowing with moderate consumer spending, and that import surges to avoid tariff implementation could weigh on US GDP estimates.
6. The US State Department said on Wednesday (16/4) that US Secretary of State Marco Rubio met with Indonesian Foreign Minister Sugiono to discuss tariff negotiations and deepen defence and security cooperation. The State Department also mentioned that Rubio welcomed Indonesia's efforts. Previously, in a tariff negotiation proposal, Indonesia proposed importing US goods worth USD 18-19 billion and offering Indonesian state-owned enterprises to invest in US oil, gas, and information-technology sectors.
7. Indonesia's Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources on Wednesday (16/4) awarded five oil and gas blocks to winning companies as an effort to replenish hydrocarbon reserves. Reuters reported that the government plans to offer nearly 60 blocks over the coming years to reverse a decade-long production decline.
8. The European Union regulator changed the compliance-document submission period for the anti-deforestation law to once a year, easing the previous requirement of submitting documents for each shipment. The rule change follows industry pressure and a postponement of the law's implementation to 30 December 2025. In June 2025, the EU will publish a categorisation of importing countries into high-risk, standard, or low-risk groups, with low-risk importers receiving lighter compliance requirements.

tickerNews.title: PTPP reports new contract value of approximately IDR 6.3 trillion in 1Q25, up 32% YoY
tickerNews.content: $PTPP: PT PP recorded a new contract value of about IDR 6.3 trillion during 1Q25, representing a 32% year-on-year increase and equal to 21% of the 2025 target. The realization came from state-owned enterprise projects accounting for 52.1%, private sector projects 28.6%, and government projects 19.3%. By work type, the port sector contributed 37.2%, buildings 32.9%, roads and bridges 22.6%, dams 4.3%, irrigation 2.8%, and oil and gas 0.3%.

tickerNews.title: SMRA records marketing sales of IDR 877 billion in 1Q25
tickerNews.content: $SMRA: Summarecon Agung reported marketing sales of IDR 877 billion in 1Q25, up 8% YoY but down 49% quarter-on-quarter, equal to 17.5% of the 2025 target of IDR 5 trillion. The residential segment contributed 75% of marketing sales, followed by shophouses at 22%, apartments at 2%, and land parcels and office space each below 1%.

tickerNews.title: DMAS reports marketing sales of IDR 466 billion in 1Q25
tickerNews.content: $DMAS: Puradelta Lestari recorded marketing sales of IDR 466 billion in 1Q25, down 17% YoY but up 9% QoQ, representing roughly 26% of the 2025 target of IDR 1.81 trillion. Director & Company Secretary Tondy Suwanto said the company sold industrial land of 14.2 hectares in 1Q25, with 86% coming from data-center projects. He added that there is still demand for about 80 hectares of industrial land, giving optimism to reach the 2025 marketing-sales target.

tickerNews.title: CLEO plans to distribute bonus shares worth IDR 240 billion
tickerNews.content: $CLEO: Sariguna Primatirta plans to distribute bonus shares valued at IDR 240 billion from share premium with a 1:1 ratio. The cum-date on the regular market and negotiation will be on 5 June 2025, with distribution on 26 June 2025. The plan will be discussed at the extraordinary shareholders meeting on 26 May 2025.

tickerNews.title: TPIA acquires 99.9% of Chandra Shipping International and Marina Indah Maritim
tickerNews.content: $TPIA: Chandra Asri Pacific, through its subsidiary Chandra Daya Investasi, signed purchase agreements for 50.99% of the shares of PT Chandra Shipping International and PT Marina Indah Maritim, with transaction values not disclosed. After the transactions, PT Chandra Daya Investasi holds 99.9% of PT Chandra Shipping International and PT Marina Indah Maritim.

tickerNews.title: EXCL shares sold by Axiata Investments (Indonesia) for IDR 7.6 trillion
tickerNews.content: $EXCL: One of the controlling shareholders of XL Axiata Telecom Sejahtera, Axiata Investments (Indonesia) Sdn. Bhd., sold 2.4 billion EXCL shares at IDR 3,189 per share, totaling IDR 7.6 trillion, to entities belonging to the Sinar Mas group. The transaction is part of the merger between EXCL and Smartfren Telecom ($FREN). After the sale, Axiata Investments' ownership in EXCL fell from 66.25% to 34.8%, contributing IDR 7.6 trillion to foreign outflow on Wednesday (16/4). The Indonesia Stock Exchange also officially delisted FREN on Thursday (17/4) following the completion of the merger.

tickerNews.title: BJBR appoints new commissioners and approves dividend of approximately IDR 897 billion
tickerNews.content: $BJBR: The shareholders of Bank Pembangunan Daerah Jawa Barat dan Banten appointed Mardigu Wowiek Prasantyo as the lead commissioner, Helmy Yahya as an independent commissioner, and Yusuf Saadudin as the president director on Wednesday (16/4). The shareholders also approved a dividend for fiscal year 2024 of about IDR 897 billion, or approximately IDR 85.3 per share, representing a 65.5% dividend payout ratio and indicating a dividend yield of 9.7% as of Thursday (17/4). The cum-date and payment date have not been announced.

tickerNews.title: ESSA announces dividend of approximately IDR 172.3 billion for FY 2024
tickerNews.content: $ESSA: ESSA Industries Indonesia will distribute a dividend for fiscal year 2024 of about IDR 172.3 billion, or IDR 10 per share, representing a 25% dividend payout ratio. The cum-date and payment date have not been announced. Based on the closing price of ESSA on Thursday (17/4) at IDR 615 per share, the implied dividend yield is 1.6%.
